column4: you've disabled the external volume control for everything, _except_ mplayer??
I've disabled the 'volume up' and 'volume down' shortcuts in the keyboard shortcuts dialog, so it no longer affects the 'master' volume, but mplayer is still affected by the volume wheel
just tape the wheel. do you know whether the hardware is doing the volume change all by itself, or if the change request is routed through the kernel?
I know the wheel is only affecting mplayer, not totem, xine, etc.  I don't know more.
taping it is a good idea.  so it WAS a hardware problem after all!  :)
the wheel is not affecting xine. did you do something to xine to make it so?
I may have lied about xine.  Sorry.  I know it doesn't affect totem though.  I don't even have xine installed.  I don't know what came over me,.
did you do something to totem to make it so?
nope, other than clearing out the 'keyboard shortcuts' for "volume up" and "volume down" in the system keyboard shortcut dialog
can you devise an experiment to determine whether this is what disabled the volume wheel for totem? maybe the volume wheel is just a fancy keyboard add-on and the system sees it as keyboard events?
the system sees the wheel as "XF86AudioRaiseVolume" and "XF86AudioLowerVolume" events
are those x11 events, visible with, say, xev?
do you have buttons on your keyboard to turn the volume up and down?  like dedicated multimedia keys?
xev shows this: http://paste.ubuntu.com/512712/
xmodmap seems to be the right tool here, but i've never used it. pase the output of xmodmap -pk
*paste
xmodmap -pk output: http://paste.ubuntu.com/512726/
echo 'keycode 122 =' | xmodmap -; echo 'keycode 123 =' | xmodmap -
did it work
I was trying to find xmodmap commands that worked for myself and didn't notice you.
it works, thanks.  I think this is a little tidier, but is really the same thing: xmodmap -e "keycode 122 ="; xmodmap -e "keycode 123 =";
nice :)
thanks so much.  now I can go watch House and not have to worry about what my belly is doing.
